title: 115_hr5036
content: The "Financial Technology Protection Act" prioritizes investigating terrorist and illicit use of new financial technology, including digital currencies. Congress emphasizes the need for an Independent Financial Technology Task Force. The Independent Financial Technology Task Force is established with key members from various government agencies and the private sector, including those with experience in the Fintech industry. Its duties include conducting research on terrorist and illicit use of financial technology. The Independent Financial Technology Task Force conducts research on terrorist and illicit use of new financial technologies, including digital currencies, and develops legislative and regulatory proposals to improve counter-terrorist and counter-illicit financing efforts. The Task Force issues an annual report to Congress containing findings, determinations, and proposals. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Attorney General, will establish a fund to pay rewards up to $450,000 for information leading to the conviction of individuals involved in terrorist use of digital currencies. Fines and forfeitures related to such convictions will be used to pay rewards and any remaining amounts will be deposited in the FinTech Leadership in Innovation Program. The FinTech Leadership in Innovation Program will receive remaining amounts from fines and forfeitures related to convictions for terrorist use of digital currencies. The "FinTech Leadership in Innovation Program" is established and funded under section 4(b)(2). The Secretary of the Treasury will provide grants for developing tools to detect terrorist and illicit use of digital currencies. Eligible recipients include entities in the United States, such as academic institutions, companies, and nonprofit organizations. The grants can be used for the development of tools and programs to detect such activities. The Secretary may provide grants for pilot programs, test cases, and research related to developing tools to detect terrorist and illicit use of digital currencies. Preferences include nonproprietary technology, open-source code, and proactive tools meeting regulatory requirements. The Secretary may provide grants for developing tools to detect terrorist and illicit use of digital currencies. New technology must adhere to existing global standards and support current laws and regulations, such as the Bank Secrecy Act. The Secretary may provide grants for developing tools to detect terrorist and illicit use of digital currencies, adhering to global standards and regulations like the Bank Secrecy Act. Tools developed with grants must be freely accessible to the public. The curr_chunk is a section on definitions. The curr_chunk defines the terms "Bank Secrecy Act" and "digital currency." The Bank Secrecy Act includes specific sections of various laws, while digital currency is described as a digital representation of value used for exchange, account, or value storage, excluding certain transactions. The curr_chunk defines the term "terrorist" and includes a person involved in domestic or international terrorism as per the definitions in the United States Code. The curr_chunk states that the document was passed by the House of Representatives on September 26, 2018, with attestation by Karen L. Haas, Clerk.
